message: My thoughts on Go. I'd love to hear your feedback about the content and the style of writing.
story: Muhammad Bassem shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Beginner Thoughts on Go
caption: blog.mbassem.com
description: A few months ago, I couldn't answer the "What's your main programming language?" question. I found out about Google's golang and started learning it. In this blog post I'll write about some of my thoughts on Go after I've been using it for a few months now.

data.message: I always thought go is to similar too cpp, and that's why I love it

nice article, 
- it seems that Go shares some ideas with scala (GC, one-liners, native concurrency model, )
- it looks that "defer" is same as context mgr in python: "with ... ():"
- it is not clear how to manage the goroutines as well, how many threads are spawned? are they context-switched? or each routine has its own thread?
- python and scala (and java) come with a lot of standard libraries that make our life easier, and "trusted" non-standard libraries with large adoption that make our life even more easier :D I wonder if this is the case in go
- how does network stack work in go? is it comparable to erlang/python/scala?
- I don't like GC since it might add unpredictability at run time (at least for critical tasks) can we turn it off in go?
Go is a fantastic language but depends on your needs. also still the debugging in GoLang is not that mature yet and you need to be expert in low level programming specially for debugging GO.
